Award.AwardTitle: The Shape of Data: A New Way to Detect Critical Shifts in System Performance

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is about a new way to detect and classify shifts in the patterns of measurements taken by sensors. Subtle shifts in the output from a vibration sensor on a bridge abutment, for instance, can indicate that a crack is developing in that structure. Identifying these shifts can be a real challenge because modern sensors can generate so much information, and so quickly. Existing approaches to this use the mathematics of statistics: averages, variability, and the like. This project uses techniques from topology, the branch of mathematics that is concerned with shape, to detect these kinds of shifts.

This project will develop techniques to assess and characterize temporal patterns in nonstationary time-series data. The project will compute aspects of the homology---e.g., the first few Betti numbers---of the stream "on the fly" to obtain a signature of its regime. To mitigate the computational burden of traditional techniques, this project uses a simplicial complex based on a small, representative set of "landmarks," with the remaining data, the "witnesses," defining the connections. New techniques include a generalization of the oft-used false near-neighbor method to evaluate the fidelity of the topology of the reconstruction, efficient selection of landmarks and choice of witness relation, classification of structure through multi-parameter persistent homology of embedded data, and development of a map on the witness complex to obtain a dynamical signature of each regime. The goals include efficient detection of regime shifts, the development of a catalog of signatures within regimes, and the detection and mitigation of noise. The classification techniques will be applicable, for example, to the detection of failure modes in manufacturing systems, malware attacks on a network, incipient heart problems, or an impending containment failure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PIs Bradley and Meiss, together with graduate students Joshua Garland (PhD 2016), Nikki Sanderson (PhD 2019), Varad Deshmukh, and Samantha Molnar, and a team of undergraduate researchers (Maxine Hartnett, Joseph Giesz, Elliot Shugerman, Jack Spicer and Jamie Tucker-Foltz), studied the methods of computational topology, the fundamental mathematical description of shape, to analyze data streams for the purpose of detecting regime shifts, where a system transitions from one operating regime to another. A challenge here is that the data are arriving in real time and the analysis must proceed accordingly---rather than post facto, with the leisure of time. Data streams are ubiquitous, especially in the age of the "internet-of-things," and detecting regime shifts in these streams has a wide range of potential applications (e.g., the incipient failure of a bearing in a lathe or the concrete deck of a bridge).
A data stream can be thought of as having a shape when it is viewed geometrically, using the method of time delays to extract and expose the causal relationships that are inherent in its patterns. Computational topology approaches this problem by viewing the data on various scales (e.g., by blowing up each point into a ball and analyzing the resulting shape, then repeating with different radius balls).
Data considered in this research included streams generated by chaotic equations, neural networks, musical instruments, power grids, and sunspot images. As one simple example, the shape of the signal can distinguish single notes played by different musical instruments. There are many important engineering and scientific applications. Cascading failures and blackouts manifest as topological shifts in the frequency data from power grids. Topology may enable better predictions of solar eruptions from temporally evolving images of sunspots, and this has spawned an ongoing collaboration with SWx-TREC, the CU Boulder Space Weather laboratory.
A portion of this research studied novel and efficient methods for constructing “complexes” from point cloud data. A complex is essentially a way to create a mesh that fills in the structure between a set of points. More formally, a complex is a generalization of a graph, which has nodes and edges, to include multiple relationships (simplices). The “witness complexes” in the PIs' study can be much more efficient than standard methods, and this is important if “on-the-fly" regime detection is to be possible. Significant shape changes can be detected in these complexes using a tool called the “persistence diagram,” which records scale-dependent components and holes (the “Betti numbers”) in the data.
The project resulted in the creation of software system called PHETS (persistent homology for embedded time series) to extract shape information (Betti numbers and persistence diagrams) from a time series. This package is available on the public archive, GitHub.
